review.title: PR2: A Language Independent Unsupervised Tool for Personality Recognition from Text
review.abstract: We present PR2, a personality recognition system available online, that performs instance-based classification of Big5 personality types from unstructured text, using language-independent features. It has been tested on English and Italian, achieving performances up to f=.68.

metadata.title: PR2: A Language Independent Unsupervised Tool for Personality Recognition from Text

sections.text: We present PR2, an online personality recognition system that uses language-independent characteristics to perform an example-based classification of Big5 personality types from unstructured text. It has been tested in English and Italian and achieves performances up to f =.68.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Background
sections.text: Personality is an affect processing system that describes persistent human behavior responses to broad classes of environmental stimuli (Adelstein et al. 2011); it has been formalized in various ways, such as the Myers-Briggs type indicator (Briggs & Myers 1980), which defines four personality types; and the Big5 (Costa & MacCrae 1992), which defines five bipolar traits, which is widely used in the scientific community and can be evaluated using various questionnaires; the Big5 traits are: extroversion, emotional stability / neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience; written text conveys a lot of information about the author's personality (Mairesse et al. 2007); and text personality recognition is an NLP task partially related to styometry (Luyckx & Daelemans 2008), which consists in the automatic classification of the author's personality traits (Maise et al 2007).

sections.heading: 2 Previous Work, Problems and Perspectives
sections.text: Following the initial groundbreaking work on personality recognition in blogs and offline texts (Oberlander & Nowson 2006; Mairesse et al 2007), there has recently been a growing interest in personality recognition from social networks and in languages other than English (Kermanidis 2012; Bai et al 2012; Quercia et al. 2011; Golbeck et al 2011).Almost all approaches to personality recognition from text are oversed.The main problems with this approach are the limitations on data annotation and language dependency.Data labelled with personality types are usually costly and time-consuming to collect. Furthermore, models trained in a particular field or language are not particularly effective when applied in different areas.The language problem also affects the language dependence of resources, such as LIWC (Tausczik & Pennebaker 2010) and MRC (Coltheart 1981).These are clear limitations in the exploitation of text of personality recognition from other LPs.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments: Testing the System
sections.text: We tested the system on two sets of data of different size, domain and language: Essays (Mairesse et al 2007), a large collection of English essays, and PersFB (Celli & Polonio 2013), a small set of Facebook posts in Italian. We divided essays into lines to have more or less the same length per text in the two sets (19 words per text in essays and 12 words per text in PersFB). As a test set, we used a sample of 250 essay authors and about 25 authors for PersFB. Patterns (parameter t) were extracted from larger sets of data: 2000 essay authors and about 1000 authors for PersFB. Since each personality trait is bipolar, we decided to cancel the tests, considering the correct predictions for both poles as true positives, false positives as false predictions and false negatives as missed predictions.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We introduced PR2: an online NLP tool for language-independent, unsupervised unlabeled text personality recognition. Unlike monitored systems that require large labeled records for training, this tool only requires a small labeled record to validate the annotation. In the future, we want to improve the accuracy of the system and provide a goal scorer for validation.
